THE TIMES-DISPATCH: RICHMOND, VA., SUNDAY

TABLET
UNVEILING

Memorials Erected in Gloucester
Courthouse to Distinguished
Sons of That County.
WAS AN INSPIRING OCCASION

A Large Assembly Hear Inter-
esting Addresses in Present-
ing and Receiving Memorials.
(Special to The Times-Dispatch.)

GLOUCESTER C. H., VA., Dec. 12.--
The Gloucester Courthouse building was
filled to repletion on Thursday by a rep-
resentative audience, who assembled to
do honor to the unveiling of tablets and
portraits of distinguished Gloucester men.
The walls of the old building are adorned
with many such memorials, but none
will be held with more reverence than
those unveiled to-day.

Judge T. R. B. Wright, to whose genius
the people of his circuit owe the thought
of placing such memorials on their court-
house walls, presided over the occasion
with his usual genial charm of manner.
In all there were about nineteen speak-
ers, and though the ceremonies were
continued without intermission from 11:30
A. M. to 4:30 P. M., there was no sign of
weariness in the audience; in fact, there
was small cause for boredom, for each
speech was a gem, some of purest ray,
and brief and to the point.
OPENING EXERCISES.

The meeting opened with prayer by the
“Fighting Parson.” honored of all men
in Gloucester, the Rev. W. E. Royall,
and the singing of “America” in fine
style.

The first tablet to be unveiled was one
in memory of Judge J. M. Gregory, judge
of this circuit from 1860 to 1865. This
tablet was erected by the court through
the generosity of Mesdame and Mr.
Gregory Galbraith, of Spartanburg, S. C.,
the daughter and his grandson, Mes-
dame A. Caskie Thomas, of New York,
and was received by Hon. D. Gardiner
Tyler in a speech replete with interesting
matter. The Hon. John Lamb, of Rich-
mond, received the same in a fine man-
ner, which will insure him a welcome
always as a speaker in Gloucester. Mas-
ter John Gregory Warburton, of Wil-
liamsburg, unveiled the tablet.
THE PAGE TABLET.

The second tablet was unveiled by Mas-
ter Mann Page, of “Shelly,” and was
the gift of Thomas Nelson Page, in mem-
ory of the many distinguished men of his
name who were born in Gloucester. This
tablet was presented by Mr. Maryus
Jones in his usual happy vein, and was
received by Mr. Joseph Bryan, who, as
be rose to speak, was met with an open-
hearted welcome by the many friends
of his youth, who are proud to claim him
as a Gloucester man. Mr. Bryan's speech
was one of the gems of the day.
MORDECAI COOK.

The third tablet was in memory of
Mordecai Cook, of Murderers' Mount,
Gloucester, and of other well known men
of that name, and was the gift of Mr.
Merritt Todd Cooke, of Norfolk, and
was presented very gracefully by Colonel
John R. Saunders and unveiled by Miss
Agnes Shackleford.

The next unveiling, Dr. Walter Reed.
M. A., LL. D., major and surgeon in the
army of the United States, who demon-
strated in Cuba the transmission of yel-
low fever by mosquitoes, was especially
interesting. Mrs. Walter Reed, widow,
and Mesdames Blincoe and Elam, sisters,
and Rev. J. C. Reed, presiding elder of
Lynchburg District, brother of Dr. Reed,
were present. Major James Carroll, of
the United States army, unveiled the tab
let, which was erected by the court of
Gloucester and a few friends. Major
Jefferson Randolph Keen, of the United
States army, whose speech is given below
in full, presented the tablet, which was
received by Dr. W. B. Robinson, of Tap-
pahannock, in a speech so chaste and so
beautiful it remains in the memory like
music. An exceedingly interestng
feature of this occasion was the
presence of Major James Carroll, who
was the first experimental case in the
mosquito test, and a warm friend of
Dr. Reed's. Dr. Reed was born in
Gloucester in 1831.
PORTRAIT UNVEILING.

The fine portrait to be unveiled was in
memory of Catesby Jones, of the Confed-
erate army, who was a type of all that
is best of Southern chivalry, and whose
short, brilliant life closed early in the
war. The portrait was unveiled by Miss
Maria Jones, and presented by Mr. Wal-
lace Williams most appropriately.

Then was unveiled the portrait of one
of Gloucester's truest and purest men,
Mr. William Ash Jones, a lawyer of abil-
ity. It was unveiled by his warm friend,
Mr. T. G. Jones, of Middlesex, in a man-
ner worthy of occasion and the man.

Judge J. L. Taliaferro, Commonwealth's
attorney, received the whole collection
in the name of the county in a very
graceful speech, and was followed by Mr.
Thomas Dowing, of Lancaster, who
made an eloquent tribute in which he said
the tablets which adorned the wall were
but types of the sort of men Gloucester
in part and Virginia in whole had and
could produce. Major G. N. Stubbs, who
also was appointed to receive the col-
lection as a whole, now arose and gave
the surprise of the day.
JUDGE WRIGHT'S PORTRAIT.

He asked Judge Wright to allow Rev.
W. E. Wiatt to take the chair, and then
presented to the crowd a most excellent
portrait of his honor, Judge Wright. It
was received with a very whoop of ap-
plause, which testified to the love and ad-
miration of the people of Gloucester to
the retiring judge, who is now holding
the last term of the Ninth Judicial Cir-
cuit of Virginia. The portrait was un-
veiled by the pretty little granddaughter
of Mr. Stubbs. Surely the burning words
of Mr. Stubbs must have gratified the
recipient of the compliment. Colonel J.
R. Saunders, of Saluda, presented this
portrait in a most delicate, touching
manner, and in the same way it was
received by Mr. Herbert Lewis, of West
Point, who convulsed the audience by
saying: “If I had been born in Gloucester
I would have been a great man.” Pos-
sibly he may yet attain. His speech cer-
tainly gave such promise.
AN ABSENTEE.

A letter read by the judge from Thomas
Nelson Page told of his profound regret
at not being able to be present, an im-
portant engagement at Yale alone pre-
vented his appearing. Mrs. Galbraith
received a telegram when she reached
Baltimore, which recalled her to Spar-
tanburg. Lines from Miss Molly Elliot
Seawell, Mr. Cook, Major T. S. Talia-
ferro, and Judge Wellford expressed re-
gret at not being able to attend the ex-
ercises. Among the visitors present from
a distance were Mesdames Caskie Thom-
as, of New oYrk; Walter Reed Blimroe,
and Elam, Rev. J. C. Reed, the Messrs.
Gardner Tyler, John Lamb, Maryus
Jones, Joseph Bryan, Johnathan Bryan,
John R. Saunders, Messrs. James Car-
roll and J. R. Reed, of United States
army; W. B. Robinson, T. G. Jones and
John Waidurim, and three ladies and
gentlemen were the guests at dinner of
Mesdames Charles E. Gary and Mrs.
W. E. Corr. The day was an inspiring
one, and to Judge Wright, who all part
with, with sincere sorrow. To his able
assistant, Hon. J. N. Stone, is due the
success of the occasion.
MAJOR KEAN'S ADDRESS.

One of the most interesting features of
the day was the unveiling of the tablet
to Major Walter Reed surgeon United
States army, by the County Court. The
presentation speech, which was made by
Major Jefferson Randolph Kean, was as
follows:

"I am here by order of the Honorable
Court of Gloucester--not to make a speech,
for I am the only Virginian in the whole
circle of my acquaintances who has not
that accomplishment--but to lay my tri-
bute of a laurel leaf on this memorial
which you have raised at this, his
words about the
great and lovable qualities of Walter
Reed and the magnitude of the work
which he accomplished. In my story I
hope you will pardon some personal allu-
sions and reminiscences--for though I did
not have the honor to be a member of the
Yellow Fever Commission, I was its confi-
dent and later its business manager and
distributing agent. His parents were
Lemuel Sutton Reed, who at the time of
Walter's birth was the presiding elder of
the Methodist Church of this circuit, and
Pharaba White, his wife. Their home
was at a little place, scarcely a village,
called Belle Roy, about six miles from
this courthouse, and there, Walter, the
youngest of five children, saw the light
on the 13th of September, 1851. I often
wonder if Dr. William Waller, the good
physician who presided on that momen-
tous occasion, was blest with any pre-
monition of the fact that the helpless
babe which he held in his hands while it
drew its first wailing breaths, was
destined to solve that riddle of the
Sphynx among diseases, and put an end
to the tribute of human lives which for
ages had been continually exacted for the
failure to guess the secret
DR. REED'S CHILDHOOD.

The infancy and childhood of the little
Walter passed without events worthy of
note in other than a mother's chronicle;
unless it may interest a Gloucester au-
dience to know that he early developed a
taste for the good things for which the
county is famous and attempted his first
oyster at the age of one month. Fortu-
nately, Dr. Waller was near at hand.
His school of education was received at
Charlottesville from Mr. William R. Ab-
bot, who is still at the head of one of
the best of our Virginia high schools, at
whose feet I too sat in my youthful
days, and to whose scholarly zeal and
patience I am indebted for the small
Latin and less Greek that still lingers in
my memory along with many pleasant re-
collections of boyish days.

It enables us to appreciate alike the re-
markable preciousness of the youth and
the limited field of medical knowledge
thirty-five years ago as compared with
our four and five years' course of to-
day to learn that he graduated in medi-
cine at the University of Virginia before
the age of eighteen, and after one year's
study. Fortunately so forced a curiculum
was supplemented by several years' of
careful study in the schools and hospitals
of New York. In 1875 he entered the medi-
cal corps of the army. He took this step,
I suspect, not so much from a love of
camps and adventures or a desire.
To follow over sea and land.
Through cities and through solitudes.
The phantom with the beckoning hand.

Which still allures and still eludes,
as from a gentler and tenderer motive--
the maiden passion for a maid. For this
position gave him an assured income,
and his marriage to the gentle lady who
is here with us to-day soon followed.
I have seen letters written by him at this
period of his life, which strike a note
unusual in a young man of twenty-four.
There is nothing of the pleasant vanities
and follies of lusty youth, or even of that
last infirmity of noble minds, desire for
fame, but only the scholar's love for his
books and a great wish to benefit man-
kind. This spirit of pure altruism greatly
impressed me twenty-five years later on
an occasion which I shall always remem-
ber and shall mention further on.

The twenty-three years of his life as an
army surgeon prior to the Spanish war
contained the usual full measure of fron-
tier service with its vicissitudes and jour-
neys and varied trials and experiences
which came to the lot of the army offi-
cer of that time. I will only note the
happy chance which in 1890 brought him
for a year to Baltimore where he was
enabled to study in the laboratory of the
foremost pathologist in America, and not
only to ground himself in the then rapid-
ly developing science of bacteriology, but
to win the esteem and affection of his
praeceptor, the illustrous and genial Dr.
Welch, of Johns Hopkins University. A
year later he was ordered to Washington
to establish the modest teaching labora-
tory of the then recently established army
medical school. His work in this labora-
tory covered a wide field of research and
was of much scientific value, but it can-
not be touched on to-day except perhaps
to mention the great and laborious in-
vestigation of the camp epidemic of
typhoid fever during the Spanish war by
the board of which he was president.
Congress last year appropriated $25,000 for
the publication of the voluminous report
of this board, a work upon which the
only surviving member, Dr. Victor C.
Vaughan, of Ann Harbor University, is
now engaged.
DR. REED IN CUBA.

In June of 1900 Dr. Reed came to Cuba
at the head of a commission for the
study of yellow fever; to attack in its
favorite stronghold that mysterious and
deadly disease which, since the days of
Columbus, had scourged the western
shores of the Atlantic from Philadelphia
to the Amazon. No one who has not read
the long catalogue of its devastations
spread through the 1,500 pages of La
Roche's monumental work can appreciate
how many thousand of lives, what oceans
of tears, what millions of money this
plague has cost humanity. It was at
that time prevalent, as usual, in Havana
and in the neighboring town of Quema-
dos, where our gallant Virginia general,
Fitzhugh Lee, had the headquarters of
his military department, and I, who hap-
pened to be chief surgeon on his staff,
was lying sick of it. So I think that, in
the visit which Reed promptly paid me,
he saw his first case of the disease with
which his fame will always be asso-
ciated.

As he often remarked, the progress of
modern medicine had stopped at this
singular disease, and no single fact was
known to us which was not to be found
in the pages of La Roche fifty years ago.
Of course, the theories of its causation
and manner of spread were infinite in
number, and more than one observer
had claimed that the bite of the mosquito
was instrumental in its propagation. Dr.
Carlos Finlay, of Havana, the most
prominent advocate of this theory, had
even correctly fixed upon the special
variety of mosquito. But scientific medi-
cine takes no note of improved theories,
and justly gives the palm of discovery
to the demonstrator of scientific facts
and not to the proclaimer of theories. I
cannot go into the causes which led Dr.
Reed's investigations into this path, ex-
cept to say that Dr. Finlay's publications
did not influence him, but more than any-
thing else the observations of another
Virginia doctor, Henry R. Carter, turned
his mind in this direction. It was evi-
dent that as man was the only creature
known to be susceptible to yellow fever,
experiments would have to be made on
human beings, and the board determined
to make the first trial on the persons of
its own members.
SACRIFICE TO SCIENCE.

Dr. James Carroll, of the army, who
is here to-day, was the first experimental
case, and suffered a very severe attack,
which carried him into the very shadow
of the gates of death. I am glad to be
able to bear witness to an act of self-
devotion as gallant as the leading of a
forlorn hope, and far more productive of
good to others, I regret to add that it has
not, however, been productive of any pro-
motion or reward for him. The third Amer-
ican member of the commission, the
young and gifted Lazear, died, nobly
sacrificing to this work a life full of
promise of scientific achievement. The
great secret was now discovered, but
more experiments were necessary to clear
up doubtful points, and accumulate a
mass of evidence which would bring con-
viction to every scientific mind. It was,
therefore, necessary to seek the assis-
tance of the military governor, whose
word was law in Cuba, and without
whose approval and financial assistance
experimentation on the scale desired
could not be conducted. Fortunately for
Cuba and for science, that military gov-
ernor was General Leonard Wood. It
was my privilege to stand with these
two in a window recess of the old palace
in Havana, overlooking the Plaza del Ar-
mas and the little chapel marking the
spot where Columbus had landed, while
Reed, with that lucidity and convincing
eloquence which he had always at his
command, told his story and made his
request. “You shall have ten thousand
dollars, and more, if that is not enough,”
was General Wood's prompt reply. If
all the accusations which jealousy and
thwarted greed are now hurling at his
back were as true as I know that they
are false, that quick and intuitive recog-
nition that this was no dreamer's tale,
and his ready assistance to this great
work would go far to balance the ac-
count.
NOT OF SELF.

Half an hour later, when Reed and
I sat at lunch in a quiet corner of the
Cafe Paris and I drank his health in
the red wine of old Spain and held forth
on the grandeur of the achievement and
the honor and fame that would be his,
he turned to me with an air of sincerity
and candor which forbade a suspicion of
cant or affectation, and said: “Keen, I
swear to you that I do not give a rap for
what this discovery will bring to me, but
I am very thankful that it has been mine
to confer so great a blessing on human-
ity.” The man spoke from his heart, and
this lofty altruism was much a part of
him, as was his fearlessness, his earn-
estness, and the merry and playful hu-
mor which bubbled through his daily con-
versation.

Of the now famous experiments at
Camp Lazear, which General Wood's
help made possible; of how our brave
hospital corps men volunteered to sleep
for weeks in bedding in which the victims
of yellow fever had died in order to prove
that the infection is not carried by cloth-
ing; of how they fearlessly bared their
arms for the bite of the infected mosquito
which alone could carry the infection--all
this makes a thrilling story; but if you
wish to hear it you must get it from Dr.
Carroll.

Our visit to General Wood happened on
the 12th of October, 1900, my note-book
tells me. In a year from that time yel-
low fever had been driven from Cuba,
never again, we hope, to return. Two
years later the Secretary of War was
writing in his report to Congress with
reference to Reed's work as follows:

“The brilliant character of this scien-
tific achievement, its inestimable value
to mankind, the saving of thousands of
lives, and the deliverance of the Atlantic
seacoast from constant apprehension, de-
mand special recognition from the gov-
ernment of the United States. I ask
that the President appoint him Assistant
Surgeon-General, with the rank of col-
onel.” But before this report had left
the hands of the printer or Walter Reed
had seen these words, his eyes were
closed in death, and that pure and lofty
spirit had gone to receive a higher and
more lasting reward.
